Content: Read the excerpt.

:box:The powers not delegated [given] to the United States by the Constitution, nor prohibited by it to the states, are reserved to the states respectively [each state], or to the people.

	—U.S. Constitution, Amendment 10
Which principle is supported by this constitutional amendment?

A.Choice: checks and balances

C.Choice: federalism

D.Choice: judicial review

Content: Which of the following was a precedent established by George Washington?

A.Choice: running for vice president

C.Choice: serving two terms as president

D.Choice: being elected to the Senate

A.Choice: the president's power to suspend the writ of habeas corpus

B.Choice: the judicial branch's ability to determine the constitutionality of laws

C.Choice: the government's power to create a national bank

D.Choice: the government's ability to regulate economic transactions

Content: Read the excerpt.

:box:Liberty of the press and of opinion is calculated [designed] to destroy all confidence between man and man.

	—U.S. Congressman

B.Choice: passage of the Intolerable Acts of 1774

C.Choice: expansion of the abolitionist movement

D.Choice: expansion of prison reforms

A.Choice: boycotted British goods

C.Choice: stopped illegal smuggling

D.Choice: established new courts in America

:box:The 15th Amendment to the Constitution states that the “right of citizens of the United States to vote shall not be denied or abridged by the United States or by any state on account of race, color, or previous condition of servitude.”

	—U.S. Constitution, National Archives
What action was intended to deny this right to African American males?

A.Choice: the use of the sharecropping system

C.Choice: the adoption of literacy tests at polling places

D.Choice: the creation of the Freedmen's Bureau

D.Choice: The purchase would reduce the country's ability to settle boundary disputes.

• many fled from the colonies after the war

A.Choice: British Soldiers

C.Choice: Patriots

D.Choice: American Indians

Content: The initial task of delegates to the 1787 Philadelphia Convention was to

A.Choice: address the problems of government under the Articles of Confederation.

B.Choice: negotiate trade agreements among the established American colonies.

C.Choice: create a document listing the grievances against Great Britain.

D.Choice: determine how to address slavery when conducting the United States census.

Content: Read the excerpt.

:box:We know our lands are now become more valuable: the white people think we don't know their value; but we are sensible that the land is everlasting, and the few goods we receive for it are soon worn out and gone.

	—Canassatego, Onondaga Chief, speaker for the Iroquois Confederacy, 1742
Based on the excerpt, what was one source of conflict between American Indians and European colonists?

A.Choice: American Indians preferred European currency rather than goods.

B.Choice: American Indians refused to teach the colonists how to farm.

C.Choice: American Indians refused to learn European languages.

D.Choice: American Indians wanted to retain their land.

A.Choice: women have no voice in the government

C.Choice: women are not allowed to serve in the military

D.Choice: state constitutions are written

B.Choice: George Washington is inaugurated as the first president.

C.Choice: The Constitution gives Congress the power to tax.

D.Choice: James Madison writes essays supporting ratification.

A.Choice: the establishment of the Ku Klux Klan

B.Choice: We will not accept this new tax on tea.

C.Choice: We must remain loyal to Great Britain and to King George.

D.Choice: We must make our own coats to protect our freedom.

Content: Read the excerpt.

:box:Representatives and direct Taxes shall be apportioned [assigned] ... according to their respective Numbers, which shall be determined by adding to the whole Number of free Persons, including those bound to Service for a Term of Years, and excluding Indians not taxed, three fifths of all other Persons [enslaved African Americans].

	—U.S. Constitution, Article 1, Section 2, Clause 3
During the Constitutional Convention, which group was satisfied by the addition of this clause?

A.Choice: factory owners in the North

C.Choice: plantation owners in the South

D.Choice: settlers in the western territories

B.Choice: to force Great Britain into an alliance with the Confederacy

C.Choice: to allow southern states to nullify federal laws

D.Choice: to prevent northern states from exporting manufactured goods

:box:One section of our country believes slavery is right and ought to be extended, while the other believes it is wrong and ought not to be extended. This is the only substantial dispute.

	—Abraham Lincoln, First Inaugural Address, 1861
Lincoln's idea expressed in this excerpt eventually led to the

A.Choice: Mexican-American War.

C.Choice: Missouri Compromise.

D.Choice: Civil War.

A.Choice: The Constitution was amended to limit the power of the president.

B.Choice: Voting rights were expanded to include most white men.

C.Choice: The federal government guaranteed the sovereignty of American Indians.

D.Choice: Congress outlawed the importation of enslaved Africans.

Content: Read the excerpt.

:box:The second question, whether the judges are invested with [given] exclusive authority to decide on the constitutionality of a law, has been ... a subject of consideration with me... Certainly there is not a word in the constitution which has given that power to them more than to the executive or legislative branches.

	—Thomas Jefferson to W.H. Torrance, 1815
Which TWO items are associated with the decision discussed in this excerpt?

A.Choice: federalism

C.Choice: judicial review

D.Choice: popular sovereignty

:ibox:This article titled “The Challenge of Sacagawea” is from the North Dakota Historical Society's website. In addition to (A) o͟f͟f͟e͟r͟i͟n͟g͟ ͟n͟e͟w͟s͟ ͟a͟n͟d͟ ͟e͟v͟e͟n͟t͟s, this website has (B) o͟n͟l͟i͟n͟e͟ ͟e͟x͟h͟i͟b͟i͟t͟s͟ ͟a͟b͟o͟u͟t͟ ͟N͟o͟r͟t͟h͟ ͟D͟a͟k͟o͟t͟a͟'͟s͟ ͟p͟a͟s͟t͟. Their mission is to (C) “͟i͟d͟e͟n͟t͟i͟f͟y͟,͟ ͟p͟r͟e͟s͟e͟r͟v͟e͟,͟ ͟i͟n͟t͟e͟r͟p͟r͟e͟t͟,͟ ͟a͟n͟d͟ ͟p͟r͟o͟m͟o͟t͟e͟ ͟t͟h͟e͟ ͟h͟e͟r͟i͟t͟a͟g͟e͟ ͟o͟f͟ ͟N͟o͟r͟t͟h͟ ͟D͟a͟k͟o͟t͟a͟ ͟a͟n͟d͟ ͟i͟t͟s͟ ͟p͟e͟o͟p͟l͟e͟.͟” The (D) a͟r͟t͟i͟c͟l͟e͟ ͟w͟a͟s͟ ͟p͟u͟b͟l͟i͟s͟h͟e͟d͟ ͟i͟n͟ ͟2͟0͟0͟3 and the website is updated regularly.

B.Choice: “... online exhibits about North Dakota's past.”

C.Choice: “... 'identify, preserve, interpret, and promote the heritage of North Dakota and its people.'”

D.Choice: “... article was published in 2003 ...”

B.Choice: following British laws rather than colonial laws

C.Choice: dumping of British tea into Boston Harbor

D.Choice: helping enslaved African Americans escape to Canada

Content: Read the excerpt.

:box:Let us then, fellow citizens, unite with one heart and one mind, let us restore ... that harmony and affection without which liberty, and even life itself, are but dreary things... We have called by different names brethren [brothers] of the same principle. We are all republicans: we are all federalists.

	—President Thomas Jefferson, Inaugural Address, 1801
Which precedent set by George Washington was Jefferson promoting in this excerpt?

A.Choice: a strict interpretation of the Constitution

C.Choice: the creation of an executive cabinet

D.Choice: the establishment of a two-term limit

Content: Read the excerpt and use it to answer the constructed response question.

:box:After freedom ... we couldn't make nothing, just overalls and something to eat. Half [your crop] went to the [farm owner] ... A man that didn't know how to count would always lose ... No matter how good account you kept, you had to go by their account ... If you didn't make no money ... they would advance [give] you more. But ... you better not try to leave and get caught. They'd keep you in debt.

	—Henry Blake, former enslaved African American, oral interview, 1936 to 1938

:ibox:• Identify the system described in this excerpt.

• Explain how the system denied economic freedoms to African Americans after the Civil War.

• Use details and examples to support your response.
What was a purpose of the Freedmen's Bureau?

A.Choice: to prevent freed African Americans from being drafted into the military

B.Choice: to assist with the removal of Union soldiers from the South

C.Choice: to prevent former Confederate soldiers from being elected to political office

D.Choice: to provide freed African Americans with access to formerly denied services

Content: Read the information.

:box:On March 3, 1863, Congress passed the Enrollment Act. It called for all male citizens and immigrants between the ages of 20 and 45 to register in a national military draft system. The act allowed for a person to be exempt from registering if he paid $300 or found a person to replace him.
What was one reaction to the Enrollment Act?

A.Choice: President Andrew Johnson was impeached.

B.Choice: Riots broke out in several Northern cities.

C.Choice: Fewer Union troops deserted.

D.Choice: States seceded from the Union.

problems/MDG8SS/media/47a.jpg
In which TWO regions did the Kansas-Nebraska Act of 1854 address the issue of slavery and lead to violence in Kansas?
Why was the Preamble included in the United States Constitution?

A.Choice: to provide a common vision of the purpose of government

B.Choice: to define the role of the judicial branch

C.Choice: to explain the levels of government

D.Choice: to identify the system of checks and balances

Content: Read the excerpt.

:box:In 1860, Elizabeth Burkett ... with her husband, Henry Burkett ... and ... fellow slaves Thomas Sipple, his wife Mary Ann Sipple, John Purnell, and Hale Burton, holding a total of thirty dollars and looking to cross the Delaware Bay into freedom ... purchased a small vessel for six dollars and began their journey up the coast on their way to Philadelphia, Pennsylvania. En route, they encountered a group of white men who attempted to overtake the slaves' boat. The fugitives, however, defended their vessel and continued on, despite injury to the passengers.

	—Archives of Maryland
What form of resistance to slavery is described in this excerpt?

A.Choice: running away

C.Choice: faking illness

D.Choice: working slowly

Content: Read the excerpt.

:box:Article VIII. All charges [costs] of war, and all other expenses that shall be incurred [raised] for the common defense or general welfare ... shall be defrayed [paid] out of a common treasury...

	—Articles of Confederation, 1781
Which limitation of the Articles of Confederation made this provision difficult to enforce?

A.Choice: the inability to collect taxes

B.Choice: the absence of an executive branch

C.Choice: the absence of a national court system

D.Choice: the inability to print a national currency

Content: Dorothea Dix led a successful campaign to help people with mental illnesses and promote

A.Choice: the abolition of slavery.

C.Choice: reforms to prison systems.

D.Choice: mandatory school attendance.

Content: Read the excerpt.

:box:America is destined for better deeds... We have no interest in (A) t͟h͟e͟ ͟s͟c͟e͟n͟e͟s͟ ͟o͟f͟ ͟a͟n͟t͟i͟q͟u͟i͟t͟y͟ ͟[͟t͟h͟e͟ ͟a͟n͟c͟i͟e͟n͟t͟ ͟p͟a͟s͟t͟], only as lessons of avoidance of nearly all their examples. (B) T͟h͟e͟ ͟e͟x͟p͟a͟n͟s͟i͟v͟e͟ ͟f͟u͟t͟u͟r͟e͟ ͟i͟s͟ ͟o͟u͟r͟ ͟a͟r͟e͟n͟a, and for our history... We are the nation of human progress, and who will ... set limits to our onward march? ... We point to the everlasting truth on (C) t͟h͟e͟ ͟f͟i͟r͟s͟t͟ ͟p͟a͟g͟e͟ ͟o͟f͟ ͟o͟u͟r͟ ͟n͟a͟t͟i͟o͟n͟a͟l͟ ͟d͟e͟c͟l͟a͟r͟a͟t͟i͟o͟n... (D) T͟h͟e͟ ͟f͟a͟r͟-͟r͟e͟a͟c͟h͟i͟n͟g͟,͟ ͟t͟h͟e͟ ͟b͟o͟u͟n͟d͟l͟e͟s͟s͟ ͟f͟u͟t͟u͟r͟e͟ ͟w͟i͟l͟l͟ ͟b͟e͟ ͟t͟h͟e͟ ͟e͟r͟a͟ ͟o͟f͟ ͟A͟m͟e͟r͟i͟c͟a͟n͟ ͟g͟r͟e͟a͟t͟n͟e͟s͟s͟. In its magnificent domain of space and time, the nation of many nations is destined to manifest to mankind ... divine principles; to establish on earth the noblest temple ... to (E) t͟h͟e͟ ͟w͟o͟r͟s͟h͟i͟p͟ ͟o͟f͟ ͟t͟h͟e͟ ͟M͟o͟s͟t͟ ͟H͟i͟g͟h — the Sacred and the True.

	—John L. O'Sullivan, 1839
Which TWO statements reflect the key components of Manifest Destiny as described in this excerpt?

A.Choice: “ ... the scenes of antiquity [the ancient past]...”

C.Choice: “... the first page of our national declaration...”

D.Choice: “The far-reaching, the boundless future will be the era of American greatness.”

E.Choice: “... the worship of the Most High...”

Content: According to the Declaration of Independence, people are able to alter or abolish the government when the government

A.Choice: no longer protects the natural rights of the people.

C.Choice: no longer allows the quartering of soldiers.

D.Choice: stops trading with foreign countries.

Content: Read the lyrics.

:box:Oh! times are tough, amazing rough,
Expenses are alarming
I will go West, it's far the best,
Try my luck at farming.
For the idea, of staying here
To just earn your gruel,
Makes me feel sad and sometimes mad
'Tis so awful cruel.
Goods are so high, I heave a sigh,
At the cost of living,
My loving wife, she sees the strife
And has a spell of crying.

	—“I Will Go West!” by J.P. Barrett, 1875
Which group's views are BEST represented by these song lyrics?

A.Choice: American Indians

C.Choice: Enslaved African Americans

D.Choice: White settlers

A.Choice: by giving more economic power to northern industrial states

B.Choice: by increasing the political influence of wealthy citizens

C.Choice: by strengthening southern and western agricultural states

B.Choice: “A strong central government is necessary for our country.”

C.Choice: “The states must retain their original powers.”

D.Choice: “The states must determine whether slavery will exist.”

A.Choice: Northwest Ordinance

C.Choice: separation of powers

D.Choice: ability to sign treaties

A.Choice: more useful

A.Choice: similar

Content: George Washington Manypenny was concerned about the impact of railroads on American Indians.
Support this claim with TWO pieces of evidence from Source B.

A.Choice: “... the railroads of the east ... will be extended westwardly ...” (Paragraph 1)

B.Choice: “... an active population will keep up with the advance of the railroads ...” (Paragraph 1)

C.Choice: “... a population that will open farms, erect workshops, and build villages and cities.” (Paragraph 1)

D.Choice: “... what the condition of the rapidly wasting Indian tribes ...” (Paragraph 1)

E.Choice: “... so sure will these poor [inhabitants] of the forest be blotted [wiped] out of existence ...” (Paragraph 2)

Content: The information in Sources A–D is credible. Use these sources to respond to the compelling question.
